title: Diffusion of proteins in chloroplast membranes

references.title: Binding of BiP to an assembly-defective protein in plant cells.
references.raw: Pedrazzini, E.A.G., Bollini, R., Ceriotti, A. and Vitale, A. (1994) Binding of BiP to an assembly-defective protein in plant cells. Plant J. 5, 103–110.

references.title: Brownian motion in biological membranes.
references.raw: Saffman, P.G. and Delbrück, M. (1975) Brownian motion in biological membranes. Proc. Nat. Acad. Sci. USA 72, 3111–3113. E. (2002) Micro-spectroscopy of chloroplasts in protoplasts from Arabidopsis thaliana under single- and multi-photon excitations. J. Lumin. 98, 107–114.

references.raw: Di Cola, A. and Robinson, C. (2005) Large-scale translocation reversal within the thylakoid Tat system in vivo. J. Cell Biol. 171, 281–289.

references.raw: Andersson, B. and Anderson, J.M. (1980) Lateral heterogeneity in the distribution of chlorophyll-protein complexes of the thylakoid membranes of spinach chloroplasts. Biochim. Biophys. Acta 593, 427–440.

references.title: Lipid diffusion in the thylakoid membranes of the cyanobacterium Synechococcus sp.: effect of fatty acid desaturation.
references.raw: Sarcina, M., Murata, N., Tobin, M.J. and Mullineaux, C.W. (2003) Lipid diffusion in the thylakoid membranes of the cyanobacterium Synechococcus sp.: effect of fatty acid desaturation. FEBS Lett. 553, 295–298.

references.title: Location and mobility of twin-arginine translocase subunits in the Escherichia coli plasma membrane.
references.raw: Ray, N., Nenninger, A., Mullineaux, C.W. and Robinson, C. (2005) Location and mobility of twin-arginine translocase subunits in the Escherichia coli plasma membrane. J. Biol. Chem. 280, 17961–17968.

references.title: Non-identical contributions of two membrane-bound cpSRP components, cpFtsY and Alb3, to thylakoid biogenesis.
references.raw: Asakura, Y., Kikuchi, S. and Nakai, M. (2008) Non-identical contributions of two membrane-bound cpSRP components, cpFtsY and Alb3, to thylakoid biogenesis. Plant J. 56, 1007–1017.

references.title: Protein diffusion and macromolecular crowding in thylakoid membranes.
references.raw: Kirchhoff, H., Haferkamp, S., Allen, J.F., Epstein, D.B.A. and Mullineaux, C.W. (2008) Protein diffusion and macromolecular crowding in thylakoid membranes. Plant. Physiol. 146, 1571–1578.

references.title: Protein lateral mobility as a reﬂection of membrane microstructure.
references.raw: Zhang, F., Lee, G.M. and Jacobson, K. (1993) Protein lateral mobility as a reﬂection of membrane microstructure. BioEssays 15, 579–588.

references.title: The reticulon and DP1/Yop1p proteins form immobile oligomers in the tubular endoplasmic reticulum.
references.raw: Shibata, Y., Voss, C., Rist, J.M., Hu, J., Rapoport, T.A., Prinz, W.A. and Voeltz, G.K. (2008) The reticulon and DP1/Yop1p proteins form immobile oligomers in the tubular endoplasmic reticulum. J. Biol. Chem. 283, 18892–18904.

references.title: The role of lipids in plastid protein transport.
references.raw: Bruce, B.D. (1998) The role of lipids in plastid protein transport. Plant Mol. Biol. 38, 223–246.

references.title: The threedimensional network of the thylakoid membranes in plants: quasihelical model of the granum-stroma assembly.
references.raw: Mustárdy, L., Buttle, K., Steinbach, G. and Garab, G. (2008) The threedimensional network of the thylakoid membranes in plants: quasihelical model of the granum-stroma assembly. Plant Cell 20, 2552–2557.

references.title: Thylakoid DpH-dependent precursor proteins bind to a cpTatC–Hcf106 complex before Tha4-dependent transport.
references.raw: Cline, K. and Mori, H. (2001) Thylakoid DpH-dependent precursor proteins bind to a cpTatC–Hcf106 complex before Tha4-dependent transport. J. Cell Biol. 154, 719–729.

abstract:
The lateral diffusion of Hcf106, a core subunit of the ΔpH-dependent translocon\ud
in higher plants, and chlorophyll-containing complexes is thoroughly investigated\ud
by Fluorescent Recovery After Photobleaching (FRAP) and Fluorescent\ud
Loss in Photobleaching (FLIP). Simple models of a thylakoid network are derived\ud
directly from confocal fluorescence microscopy images by Monte Carlo optimisation.\ud
These networks are used as the domain for diffusion simulations using the\ud
Particle Strength Exchange method, allowing determination of diffusion coefficients for the thylakoid protein Hcf106 and for chlorophyll-containing complexes.\ud
Extending the mobility studies to the chloroplast outer membrane, diffusion coefficients\ud
are estimated for Toc159, a component of the chloroplast outer membrane\ud
translocon TOC
